bibl.title: Letter from Simon Flexner to James E. Peabody, December 10, 1941

div1.p: Flexner comments on Peabody's manuscript and corrects details about Welch and Johns Hopkins Hospital.

div1.head: Letter from Simon Flexner to James E. Peabody, December 10, 1941
div1.opener:
FROM JAMES E. PEABODY
Dr. Simon Flexner
530 East 86th. St.
New York City
December 10, 1941
Dear Mr. Peabody:
div1.p:
I have read with great interest the account which you left with
me of the outstanding events leading to the successful propaganda,
under your leadership to secure recognition by Congress of the heroes
of the yellow fever experiments in Cuba.

You use this great theme to bring to the attention of teachers
and students of biology throughout the country the recent publication
of the biography of William Henry Welch who assisted you in your human-
itarian efforts. This action on your part is very gratifying to me.

As I read your remarkable story, it seems to me that if the edi-
tor wished it, you could condense the account by an omission or two
and by paraphrasing some of the lengthy statements of officials. Thus
Mrs. Kissinger's letter to you, interesting as it is, could be para-
phrased but retaining the stirring parts.

I notice one error only. You say that Welch founded the Hopkins
Hospital. Actually the Hospital was founded by Johns Hopkins of Balti-o
more. Dr. Welch was its first pathologist, and the Hospital is an in-
tegral part of the Medical School.

Of the interesting matter beyond the part strictly relating to
Dr. Welch I can offer no suggestions. II telephoned the Viking Press,
and an autographed copy of the biography will be sent you. This copy
carries my son's name as well as my own.

It was a pleasure to meet you this morning. I am greatly pleased
that you read the biography with so much pleasure.
